body:
Hi @sonoff2, looks like we're not providing a wheel for your platform (OS) which I'm assuming requires the `win_amd64.whl` wheel. We will have to figure out how to add this to our CI/CD workflows on appveyor or GitHub Actions. 

Could you try to follow the [installation instructions](https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/installation.html) to see if you can compile it locally? The error above is simply due to missing Cython.

Hello,
I followed doc instructions in
_Installation > Development version >Installing build dependencies > Windows_
and it successfully installed. Thanks !

@sonoff2 alright, great, that's good to know!

That also means that it should be quite easy to set up an addition CI/CD workflow for the `win_amd64.whl`. We should consider moving away from appveyor though as it is a lot slower than GitHub Actions or Azure.

I've had the same issue, and building the package did in fact solve it for me.
However, and forgive me for my silly question, does that mean that whenever I would like to import sktime for my project, I'd have to build it and all of its dependencies onto the project, as well?
@vaknin no, you only have to build it once, after that it's installed in your environment. Whether you have to build the dependencies depends on whether they provide the wheel that you need.

> @vaknin no, you only have to build it once, after that it's installed in your environment. Whether you have to build the dependencies depends on whether they provide the wheel that you need.

Cheers.
If it helps anyone, I found that using sktime via conda is easier and returns no errors (for amd64).

Before this code I tried 
```
pip install sktime[all_extras]
``` 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63906053/116391200-8a27ff00-a827-11eb-8454-2633fe83ae69.png)
**I finally installed sktime, but now it's for pmdarima module. :(** 


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63906053/116391289-a0ce5600-a827-11eb-9168-1d75bd90e974.png)

@mloning @mertbozkir @vaknin I'm trying to install `sktime` and `pmdarima` via conda exclusively within a feedstock, has anyone been able to install both `sktime` and `pmdarima` via conda without running into package conflict issues?
